sen.j: 平安装束（へいあんしょうぞく）は、平安時代の皇族・貴族の衣服。
sen.e: Heian-style costume is clothing worn by the Imperial families and court nobles in the Heian period.
Heian-style costume is clothing worn by the Imperial families and court nobles during the Heian period.
Heian-style costume is clothing worn by the Imperial families and court nobles during the Heian period.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 平安時代の日本の衣服については、『源氏物語絵巻』、『年中行事絵巻』、『伴大納言絵詞』などの絵巻物に描かれた人物像が重要な資料である。
sen.e: The figures in the emakimono (a picture scroll) such as "Genji monogatari emaki (The Tale of Genji Picture Scrolls)," "Nenju gyoji emaki (Picture Scroll of the Annual Rites and Ceremonies)," and "Ban dainagon emaki (Ban Major Counselor Picture Scrolls)" are important materials to know the Japanese costume during the Heian period.

The figures in the emakimono (picture scroll) such as "Genji monogatari emaki (The Tale of Genji Picture Scrolls)," "Nenju gyoji emaki (Picture Scroll of the Annual Rites and Ceremonies)," and "Ban dainagon emaki (Ban Major Counselor Picture Scrolls)" are important materials to learn about the Japanese costume during the Heian period.

The figures in the emakimono (picture scroll) such as "Genji monogatari emaki" (The Tale of Genji Picture Scrolls), "Nenju gyoji emaki" (Picture Scroll of the Annual Rites and Ceremonies), and "Ban dainagon emaki" (Ban Major Counselor Picture Scrolls) are important materials to learn about the Japanese costume during the Heian period.

sen.j: 『日本後紀』、『続日本後紀』、『日本三代実録』、『日本紀略』、そして物語・日記などの書物も当時を知る資料である。
sen.e: The following tales and diaries are also important materials: "Nihonkoki (Later Chronicle of Japan)," "Shoku Nihon Koki (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued)," "Nihon sandai jitsuroku (Veritable Records of Three Reigns of Japan)," and "Nihon kiryaku (The Abbreviated History of Japan)."

The following tales and diaries are also important materials: "Nihonkoki (Later Chronicle of Japan)," "Shoku Nihon Koki (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued)," "Nihon sandai jitsuroku (Veritable Records of Three Reigns of Japan)," and "Nihon kiryaku (The Abbreviated History of Japan)."

"Nihonkoki" (Later Chronicle of Japan), "Shoku Nihonkoki" (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued), "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (Veritable Records of Three Reigns of Japan)", "Nihon Kiryaku" (The Abbreviated History of Japan) and tales and diaries are also important materials.
sen.cmt: punctuation(書物名）原文の内容に合わせて修正

sen.j: しかし、平安時代の衣服は現在もわからないことが多い。
sen.e: However, many things regarding the costume during the Heian period are still unknown today.
However, many things regarding the costume during the Heian period are still unknown today.
However, many things regarding the costume during the Heian period are still unknown today.

sen.j: これは衣服の原材料である絹・麻などの繊維は金属・木材に比べて極めて時間経過による劣化が激しく、時代を超えて残ることが殆ど無い為である。
sen.e: Because the materials for clothing such as silk and hemp have much less durability than metal or wood, so there is almost no possibility for such materials to survive through the years.
Because materials for clothing such as silk and hemp have much less durability than metal or wood, there is almost no possibility for such materials to survive through the years.
Because materials for clothing such as silk and hemp have much less durability than metal or wood, there is almost no possibility for such materials to survive through the years.

sen.j: 平安時代も中期までは服装について奈良時代と大きく違うことはなかったが、菅原道真によって遣唐使が廃止された以降、あらゆる文化の側面に於いて中国大陸の文化の影響を離れた日本独自の国風文化が盛んになった。
sen.e: Until the Mid-Heian period, the costume had not been so different from that of the Nara period, but after SUGAWARA no Michizane abolished the envoys to Tang dynasty China, the Chinese culture became less influential and an indigenous culture developed in every aspect.

Until the Mid-Heian period, the costume had not been so different from that of the Nara period, but after SUGAWARA no Michizane abolished the envoys to Tang dynasty China, the Chinese culture became less influential and an indigenous culture developed in every aspect.

Until the mid-Heian period, the costume had not been so different from that of the Nara period, but after SUGAWARA no Michizane abolished the envoys to Tang dynasty China, the Chinese culture became less influential and an indigenous culture developed in every aspect.

sen.j: 国風文化は衣服にも現れ、特に形状に於いて大振りなものとなった。
sen.e: The indigenous culture came to appear in clothing, and especially the shape of clothes became larger.
The indigenous culture came to appear in clothing, and especially the shape of clothes became larger.
The indigenous culture came to appear in clothing, and especially the shape of clothes became larger.

sen.j: 織模様(紋)や染色技術の進展によって色彩に多様性が生まれ、朝廷における儀式行事に用いられることによって貴族の衣服は文化的な向上を見せた。
sen.e: Due to the development of woven pattern (family crest) and dying technique, the colorful clothing came to be used in ceremonial rituals in the Imperial court, showing the cultural improvement in clothing of the court nobles.

Due to the development of woven pattern (family crest) and dye techniques, colorful clothing came to be used in ceremonial rituals in the Imperial court, showing the cultural improvement in clothing of the court nobles.

Due to the development of woven pattern (design) and dye techniques, colorful clothing came to be used in ceremonial rituals in the Imperial court, showing the cultural improvement in clothing of the court nobles.

sen.j: また、大振りとなった装束に張りを持たせる為、強く糊を張った「強装束」または「剛装束」（どちらも「こわしょうぞく」）と呼ばれる着装法の登場によって、装束の形状変化は一定の終着に至った。
sen.e: In order to add firmness to the rather big costume, stiffly starched clothing called 'kowashozoku' appeared and the changes in costumes were unified into a certain style.
In order to add firmness to a rather big costume, stiffly starched clothing called 'kowashozoku' appeared and the changes in costumes were unified into a certain style.
In order to add firmness to a rather big costume, stiffly starched clothing called 'kowashozoku' appeared and the changes in costumes were unified into a certain style.

sen.j: 平安期に登場した装束はそれ以降も朝廷・幕府等の儀礼に用いられ、着装法や着装する儀式と装束の相関に様々な時代的変化を経たものの、形状等の基礎的な部分に於いては現代に至っても通底している。
sen.e: The costume that appeared during the Heian period have been used for ceremonies in the Imperial court and bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) since then, and the shape of clothing has essentially been the same until today,though the ceremonies and costumes had gone through various minor changes and had influence on each other through the years.

The costume that appeared during the Heian period had been used for ceremonies in the Imperial court and bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) since then, and the shape of clothing has essentially been the same until today, though the ceremonies and costumes had gone through various minor changes and had influence on each other through the years.

The costumes that appeared during the Heian period had been used for ceremonies in the Imperial court and bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) since then, and the shape of clothing has essentially been the same until today, though "how to wear costumes" and "how rituals and costumes related to each other" had gone through various changes through the years.
sen.cmt: 原文の内容に合わせて訳文を修正

sen.j: 考証による復元
sen.e: Restoration based on historical investigation
Restoration based on historical investigation
Restoration based on historical investigation

sen.j: 現在、平安時代以前の衣服と比べれば、平安時代の衣服のほうが、より詳しくわかっている。
sen.e: Today we know the costume during the Heian period more than that prior to the Heian period.
Today we know more about the costume during the Heian period than that prior to the Heian period.
Today we know more about the costume during the Heian period than that prior to the Heian period.

sen.j: しかし、現在の専門家が考証する場合であっても、平安時代の衣服を復元する試みにおいては、推定により作っている部分が多い。
sen.e: However, when the Heian period costume is restored, it is mostly done by presumption even though the present experts study historical evidences.
However, when the Heian period costume is restored, it is mostly done by presumption even though present experts study historical evidences.
However, when costumes in the Heian period are restored, it is mostly done by presumption even though present experts study historical evidences.
sen.cmt: 複数形のほうが良いと思います

sen.j: 現在、京都府京都市下京区に、風俗博物館があり、そこでは平安時代の日本の衣服を中心に、考証により復元された服が展示されている。
sen.e: Today, the Costume Museum is located at Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and restored clothing based on historical investigation, especially the Heian-style costumes, are exhibited.
Today, the Costume Museum is located at Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and restored clothing based on historical investigation, especially the Heian-style costumes, are exhibited.
Today, restored clothing based on historical investigation, mostly the Heian-style costumes, are exhibited at the Costume Museum in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 現代において、『源氏物語』をもとにして大衆向けの娯楽作品を制作する人や、『源氏物語』または『源氏物語』をもとにして作られた作品を愛好する人たちが少なくない。
sen.e: Some people create works for amusement based on "The Tale of Genji" today, and many people love "The Tale of Genji" itself and the works based on it too.
Some people create works for amusement based on "The Tale of Genji" today, and many people love "The Tale of Genji" itself and the works based on it as well.
Some people create works for amusement based on "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji) today, and many people love original "Genji Monogatari" and the works based on it.

sen.j: このため、専門家でない人たちが平安時代の衣服を「復元」して不特定多数に公開することがある。
sen.e: Therefore nonexperts 'restore' the Heian costume in their works, and place them on exhibition.
Therefore nonexperts 'restore' the Heian costume in their works, and place them on exhibition.
Therefore nonexperts 'restore' the Heian costume in their works, and place them on exhibition.

sen.j: しかし、そのような衣服は専門家から見れば間違いだらけのことも多い。
sen.e: However, such clothing often contain a lot of mistakes from the view of expert.
However, such clothing often contain a lot of mistakes from the view of the expert.
However, such clothing often contain a lot of mistakes from the viewpoint of experts.

sen.j: 現代における人気
sen.e: Popularity today
Popularity today
Popularity today

sen.j: 現代においては、平安時代に由来する、叉は平安時代を復元した祭りの時代行列、曲水の宴等、デパート、和服の業界団体や着付け教室主催の各種行事、等で見られる場合が多い。
sen.e: Today the Heian-style costume mostly can be seen in the following events: the parade of the Ages (a festival in which the Heian costume is restored), gokusui no utage (a drinking party for Heian period nobles at which cups of sake were floated down a winding stream and participants seated on the bank had to improvise a tanka poem before taking a sip), and some events held by department stores, industrial associations of Japanese clothes, and kimono schools.

Today the Heian-style costume mostly can be seen in the following events: the parade of the Ages (a festival in which the Heian costume is restored), gokusui no utage (a drinking party for Heian period nobles at which cups of sake were floated down a winding stream and participants seated on the bank had to improvise a tanka poem before taking a sip), and some events held by department stores, industrial associations of Japanese clothes, and kimono schools.

Today the Heian-style costume mostly can be seen in the following events: the parade of the Ages (a festival in which the Heian costume is restored), kyokusui no en (a drinking party for Heian period nobles at which cups of sake were floated down a winding stream and participants seated on the bank had to improvise a tanka poem before taking a sip), and some events held by department stores, industrial associations of Japanese clothes, and kimono schools.
sen.cmt: gokusui no utage ともいうようですが、kyokusui no en のほうが一般的だと思います。

sen.j: 礼服 (宮中)
sen.e: Formal attire (in the Imperial court)
Formal attire (in the Imperial court)
Formal attire (in the Imperial court)

sen.j: 明治天皇即位まで即位式に用いられた中国風の豪奢な装束。
sen.e: It is a Chinese-style luxurious costume worn at an enthronement ceremony, and it has actually been worn until the enthronement of the Emperor Meiji.
It is a luxurious Chinese-style costume worn at an enthronement ceremony, and it has actually been worn until the enthronement of the Emperor Meiji.
It is a luxurious Chinese-style costume worn at an enthronement ceremony, and it has in fact been worn until the enthronement of the Emperor Meiji.

sen.j: 文官束帯
sen.e: Bunkan sokutai (formal court dress for sovereign and civilian nobles)
Bunkan sokutai (formal court dress for sovereign and civilian nobles)
Bunkan sokutai (formal court dress for sovereign and civilian nobles)

sen.j: 文官の装束。
sen.e: A costume for bunkan (civil officers)
A costume for bunkan (civil officers)
A costume for bunkan (civil officers)

sen.j: 天皇、文官、三位以上の武官が着用。
sen.e: It was worn by the Emperor, bunkan and military officers of sanmi (Third Court Rank) and above.
It was worn by the Emperor, bunkan and military officers of sanmi (Third Court Rank) and above.
It was worn by the Emperor, bunkan and military officers of Sanmi (Third Rank) and above.

sen.j: 構成は内側から、小袖（こそで）、大口袴（おおぐちばかま）、単（ひとえ）、表袴（うえのはかま）、下襲（したがさね）、裾（きょ）、袍（ほうえきのほう）、石帯（せきたい）。
sen.e: It consists of, from inside to outside, kosode (a kimono with short sleeves worn as underclothing), oguchi bakama (wide-bottomed skirted trousers), hitoe (an unlined kimono), ue no hakama (over trousers), shitagasane (train-robe), kyo (a train of shitagasane), hoeki no ho (the top layer of men's formal court attire), and sekitai (a black leather belt the back of which was embedded with gemstones).

It consists of, from inside to outside, kosode (a kimono with short sleeves worn as underclothing), oguchi bakama (wide-bottomed skirted trousers), hitoe (an unlined kimono), ue no hakama (over trousers), shitagasane (train-robe), kyo (a train of shitagasane), hoeki no ho (the top layer of men's formal court attire), and sekitai (a black leather belt the back of which was embedded with gemstones).

It consists of, from inside to outside, kosode (a kimono with short sleeves worn as underclothing), oguchi bakama (wide-bottomed skirted trousers), hitoe (an unlined kimono), ue no hakama (over trousers), shitagasane (train-robe), kyo (a train of shitagasane), hoeki no ho (the top layer of men's formal court attire), and sekitai (a black leather belt the back of which was embedded with gemstones).

sen.j: 下襲の上に半臂（はんぴ）を着用することになっていたが、冬期は着なくても良い（バレない）こととなり、後に廃された。
sen.e: Hanpi (a short-sleeved, thigh-length jacket) was supposed to be worn over the shitagasane, but people were allowed not to wear it in winter (because nobody can see it), and later it was abolished.
Hanpi (a short-sleeved, thigh-length jacket) was supposed to be worn over the shitagasane, but people were allowed not to wear it in winter (because nobody can see it), and later it was abolished.
Hanpi (a short-sleeved, thigh-length jacket) was supposed to be worn over the shitagasane, but people were allowed not to wear it in winter (because nobody can see it), and later it was abolished.

sen.j: 下襲の下に衵（あこめ）を着用していたが、明治以降皇族以外は着用しないこととなった。
sen.e: Akome (a lined gown) had been worn under the shitagasane, but after the Meiji period nobody wore it except the Imperial families.
Akome (a lined gown) had been worn under the shitagasane, but after the Meiji period nobody wore it except for the Imperial families.
Akome (a lined gown) had been worn under the shitagasane, but after the Meiji period nobody wore it except for the Imperial families.

sen.j: 身分が高いほど裾が長い。
sen.e: The higher rank person's akome had a longer train.
The higher ranking person's akome had a longer train.
The higher ranking person wears the longer train.
sen.cmt: 「裾が長い」のは「あこめ」ではないと思われるので、訳文を修正。

sen.j: 中務省の官人、参議以上の官職にある者は勅許を得て大刀を佩用する。
sen.e: Officials of the Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) or those who held a position of Sangi (Councilor) and above were allowed to carry swords by the Imperial permission.
Officials of the Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) or those who held a position of Sangi (Councilor) and above were allowed to carry swords by Imperial permission.
Officials of the Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) or those who held a position of Sangi (Councilor) and above were allowed to carry swords by Imperial permission.

sen.j: 武官束帯
sen.e: Bukan sokutai (formal court dress for military officers)
Bukan sokutai (formal court dress for military officers)

sen.j: 武官の装束。
sen.e: A costume for bukan (military officers).

sen.j: 四位以下の武官が着用。
sen.e: It was worn by military officials of shii (Fourth Rank) and below.
It was worn by military officials of shii (Fourth Rank) and below.
It was worn by military officials of Shii (Fourth Rank) and below.

sen.j: なお、三位以上の武官は文官と同じ装束であり、従って黒色の武官束帯を着用していると自動的に四位の武官であると判別できる。
sen.e: Military officers of the third court rank and above wore the same clothing as bunkan, therefore those who wore black bukan sokutai were automatically identified as military officials of the fourth court rank.

Military officers of the third court rank and above wore the same clothing as bunkan, therefore those who wore black bukan sokutai were automatically identified as military officials of the fourth court rank.

Military officers of Sanmi (Third Rank) and above wore the same clothing as bunkan, therefore those who wore black bukan sokutai were automatically identified as military officials of Shii (Fourth Rank).

sen.j: 構成は内側から、小袖（こそで）、大口袴（おおぐちばかま）、表袴（うえのはかま）、単（ひとえ）、半臂（はんぴ）、下襲（したがさね）、闕腋袍（けってきのほう）、石帯（せきたい）。
sen.e: From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, oguchi bakama, ue no hakama, hitoe, hanpi, shitagasane, ketteki no ho (open sleeve seams outer robe), and sekitai.
From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, oguchi bakama, ue no hakama, hitoe, hanpi, shitagasane, ketteki no ho (open sleeve seams outer robe), and sekitai.
From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, oguchi bakama, ue no hakama, hitoe, hanpi, shitagasane, ketteki no ho (open sleeve seams outer robe), and sekitai.

sen.j: 文官の縫腋の袍と違い闕腋の袍は脇が開いているため、半臂を略することが出来ない。
sen.e: Being different from bunkan's hoteki no ho (sewn sleeve seams outer robe), ketteki no ho has an opening at the side, so hanpi must be worn.
Being different from bunkan's hoteki no ho (sewn sleeve seams outer robe), ketteki no ho has an opening at the side, so hanpi must be worn.

sen.j: 裾は下襲や袍と一体になっている。
sen.e: Kyo is connected to the shitagasane and ho.
Kyo is connected to the shitagasane and ho.

sen.j: 大刀を平緒で腰に結びつけて佩用する。
sen.e: A sword was tied around a waist with hirao (type of belt that went with the sokutai costume, from which the sword was hung).
A sword was tied around a waist with hirao (type of belt that went with the sokutai costume, from which the sword was hung).

sen.j: 衣冠
sen.e: Ikan (informal court dress for a man)

sen.j: 男性の略礼装。
sen.e: It is an informal court dress for a man.

sen.j: 元々は宮中に於ける宿直用の装束であったが、後に儀礼服化した。
sen.e: Originally it was a costume for courtiers on night duty in the Imperial court, but later it became a ceremonial costume.
Originally it was a costume for courtiers on night duty in the Imperial court, but later it became a ceremonial costume.
Originally it was a costume for courtiers on night duty in the Imperial court, but later it became a ceremonial costume.

sen.j: 構成は内側から、小袖（こそで）、単（ひとえ）、指貫（さしぬき）、下襲（したがさね）、縫腋の袍（ほうえきのほう）。
sen.e: From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, hitoe, sashinuki (gathered trousers), shitagasane, and hoeki no ho.

sen.j: 直衣
sen.e: Noshi (informal wear for noblemen)

sen.j: 狩衣
sen.e: Kariginu (hunting costume)
Kariginu (hunting costume)

sen.j: 水干
sen.e: Suikan (old plain clothes worn by court nobles)
Suikan (old plain clothes worn by court nobles)
Suikan (old plain clothes worn by court nobles)

sen.j: 狩衣と、ほぼ同じ形であるが、襟を止めるための長い紐が付いてる点と菊綴が２個づつ４ヶ所に付いてる点が異なる。
sen.e: It was almost the same shape as kariginu, but different in that suikan had a long cord to fasten a collar and two pairs of kikutoji (tassel) being attached to four places.
It was almost the same shape as kariginu, but different in that suikan had a long cord to fasten a collar and two pairs of kikutoji (tassel) being attached to four places.
It was almost the same shape as kariginu, but different in that suikan had a long cord to fasten a collar and two pairs of kikutoji (tassel) being attached to four places.

sen.j: 着方も、裾を袴の中に入れる場合と入れない場合、襟を狩衣と同様にする場合とＶ字型にする場合がある。
sen.e: The hem of suikan was sometimes tuck in the hakama, and sometimes not, and moreover, the collar was sometimes done like kariginu and sometimes formed into a V-shape.
The hem of suikan was sometimes tucked into the hakama, and sometimes not, and moreover, the collar was sometimes done like kariginu and sometimes formed into a V-shape.
The hem of suikan was sometimes tucked into hakama, and sometimes not, and moreover, the collar was sometimes done like kariginu and sometimes formed into a V-shape.

sen.j: 十二単と通称され、現在では最高の女性の装束とされる。
sen.e: It is commonly called juni hitoe (twelve-layered robe), and now considered the supreme costume for a woman.
It is commonly called juni hitoe (twelve-layered robe), and now considered the supreme costume for a woman.
It is commonly called juni hitoe (twelve-layered robe), and now considered the supreme costume for a woman.

sen.j: 構成は内側から、小袖（こそで）、長袴（ながばかま）、単（ひとえ）、五衣（いつつぎぬ）、打衣（うちぎぬ）、表衣（うわぎ）、唐衣（からぎぬ）、裳（も）。
sen.e: From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, naga bakama (long hakama), hitoe, itsutsuginu (five-layered robe), uchiginu (a lustrous silk robe), uwagi (outer robe), karaginu (a waist length Chinese style jacket), and mo (long pleated skirts).

From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, naga bakama (long hakama), hitoe, itsutsuginu (five-layered robe), uchiginu (a lustrous silk robe), uwagi (outer robe), karaginu (a waist length Chinese style jacket), and mo (long pleated skirts).

From inside to outside, it consists of kosode, naga bakama (long hakama), hitoe, itsutsuginu (five-layered robe), uchiginu (a lustrous silk robe), uwagi (outer robe), karaginu (a waist length Chinese style jacket), and mo (long pleated skirts).

sen.j: 物具装束(もののぐしょうぞく、平安末期までの正装)では上記に比礼（ひれ）、桾帯（くんたい）を追加、髪の毛を結い上げ、宝冠（ほうかん）を追加、奈良時代の風俗を残す。
sen.e: In addition to the clothes mentioned above, Mononogu shozoku (a formal wear worn until the late Heian period) contained hire (cloth sash hung from the shoulders) and kuntai (cloth sash hung from the waist), with the hair done up and hokan (crown) on top of the head, in which Asuka period customs remained.

In addition to the clothes mentioned above, Mononogu shozoku (a formal wear worn until the late Heian period) contained hire (cloth sash hung from the shoulders) and kuntai (cloth sash hung from the waist), with the hair done up and hokan (crown) on top of the head, in which Asuka period customs remained.

In addition to the clothes mentioned above, Mononogu shozoku (a formal wear worn until the late Heian period) contained hire (cloth sash hung from the shoulders) and kuntai (cloth sash hung from the waist), with the hair done up and hokan (crown) on top of the head, in which the Nara period customs remained.

sen.j: 小袖の色は常に白、袴は捻襠(ねじまち)仕立てで、色は平安時代には未既婚にかかわらず常に緋とされたが江戸時代以降は未婚者は濃紫(こき)、既婚者は緋とされた。
sen.e: The color of kosode was always white; hakama was pleated and its color was always scarlet regardless of an unmarried or married during the Heian period; after the Edo period, an unmarried woman wore a deep violet hakama, while a married woman wore a scarlet hakama.

The color of kosode was always white; hakama was pleated and its color was always scarlet regardless of an unmarried or married during the Heian period; after the Edo period, an unmarried woman wore a deep violet hakama, while a married woman wore a scarlet hakama.

The color of kosode was always white; hakama was pleated and its color was always scarlet in the Heian period regardless of marriage status; after the Edo period, an unmarried woman wore a deep violet hakama, while a married woman wore a scarlet hakama.

sen.j: 袿を参照。
sen.e: See uchigi (layers of gowns).
sen.cmt: 原文の意味が通らないため、ウィキペディアを参照したところ、以下のように「袿袴」という見出しがあり、本文が「袿を参照」となっていました。ここでは「袿を参照」と解釈して訳しています。袿袴袿を参照
sen.e: See uchigi (layers of gowns).
See uchigi (layers of gowns).

sen.j: 采女装束
sen.e: Uneme (a maid-in-waiting at the court) costume
Uneme (a maid-in-waiting at the court) costume
Uneme (a maid-in-waiting at the court) costume

sen.j: 水干
sen.e: Suikan
sen.cmt: 見出し語が本文に入りこんでいたため、ウィキペディアを参照して新に行を追加しました。
sen.e: Suikan
Suikan

sen.j: 男性の水干と同様であるが必ず白になる。
sen.e: It is the same as the suikan for a man, but always white.
sen.cmt: 見出し語「水干」が本文の先頭に入り込んでいたため（「水干男性の～」）、行を追加して分離しました。
sen.e: It is the same as the suikan for a man, but always white.
It is the same as the suikan for a man, but always white.

sen.j: 裾を緋の長袴(唐衣裳装束と共通)の中に入れ、金の烏帽子を被る。
sen.e: The hem of suikan was tucked in the naga bakama (common to the karaginumo shozoku which is popularly called juni hitoe) and a golden lacquered hat was worn.
The hem of suikan was tucked in the naga bakama (common to the karaginumo shozoku which is popularly called juni hitoe) and a golden lacquered hat was worn.
The hem of suikan was tucked in naga bakama (common to the karaginumo shozoku which is popularly called juni hitoe) and a golden lacquered hat was worn.

tit.e: The costumes for boys and girls
The costumes for boys and girls
The costumes for boys and girls

sen.j: 半尻
sen.e: Hanjiri
Hanjiri
Hanjiri (Literally, half of the buttocks)

sen.j: 狩衣の少年版。
sen.e: This is a kariginu for a boy.
This is a kariginu for a boy.
This is a kariginu for a boy.

sen.j: 後身頃が尻の半分くらいまでであることが名前の由来。
sen.e: It was named after the two back panels of a kimono which cover half of the buttocks.
It was named after the two back panels of a kimono which cover half of the buttocks.
It was named after the two back panels of a kimono which cover half of the buttocks.

sen.j: 水干
sen.e: Suikan
Suikan
Suikan

sen.j: 男性の水干と同様であるが菊綴が5ヶ所となり、背中の菊綴が両肩に付く点が異なる。
sen.e: It is almost the same as the suikan for a man, but this one has five kikutoji and they are attached on the shoulders instead of the back.
It is almost the same as the suikan for a man, but this one has five kikutoji and they are attached on the shoulders instead of the back.
It is almost the same as the suikan for a man, but this one has five kikutoji and they are attached on the shoulders instead of the back.

sen.j: 又、袴にも菊綴が付く。
sen.e: Hakama also has kikutoji.
Hakama also has kikutoji.
Hakama also has kikutoji.

sen.j: 細長
sen.e: Hosonaga (long divided robe)
Hosonaga (long divided robe)
Hosonaga (long divided robe)

sen.j: 現行の細長は袿に似てるが衽(おくみ)が無い点が異なる（その下の単には衽がある）。
sen.e: The present hosonaga is similar to uchigi, but it has no okumi (a gusset). (Hitoe under the uchigi has it.)
The present hosonaga is similar to uchigi, but it has no okumi (a gusset). (Hitoe has okumi under the uchigi)
The present hosonaga is similar to uchigi, but it has no okumi (a gusset). (Hitoe has okumi under the uchigi)

sen.j: 小袖、袴、単、共に濃紫になる。
sen.e: Kosode, hakama, and hitoe are all deep violet.
Kosode, hakama, and hitoe are all deep violet.
Kosode, hakama, and hitoe are all deep violet.

sen.j: 細長の袍（闕腋（けってき）の袍の少年版、袴は表袴）を指す場合もある。
sen.e: It sometimes refers to hosonaga no ho (ketteki no ho for boys, and hakama is ue no hakama).
It sometimes refers to hosonaga no ho (ketteki no ho for boys, and hakama is ue no hakama).
It sometimes refers to hosonaga no ho (ketteki no ho for boys, and hakama is ue no hakama).

sen.j: 汗衫
sen.e: Kazami (young girl's formal costume)
Kazami (young girl's formal costume)
Kazami (young girl's formal costume)

sen.j: 本来は下着のこと。
sen.e: It originally referred to an undergarment.
It originally referred to an undergarment.
It originally referred to an undergarment.

sen.j: 現在は絽、紗、等の薄物で単と同様に仕立てた袿の一種。
sen.e: However, it means a kind of uchigi made of light stuff like silk gauze and sewed in the same way as hitoe.
However, it means a kind of uchigi made of light material like silk gauze and sewed in the same way as hitoe.
However, it means a kind of uchigi made of light material like silk gauze and sewed in the same way as hitoe.

sen.j: 小袖と袴は共に濃紫になるが単は汗衫と共に明るい華やかな色彩になる。
sen.e: Both kosode and hakama are deep violet, but hitoe and kazami have bright and gorgeous color.
Both kosode and hakama are deep violet, but hitoe and kazami have bright and gorgeous colors.
Both kosode and hakama are deep violet, but hitoe and kazami have bright and gorgeous colors.

sen.j: 薄物で仕立てた細長の袍を指す場合もある。
sen.e: Sometimes it refers to hosonaga no ho made of thin material.
Sometimes it refers to hosonaga no ho made of thin material.
Sometimes it refers to hosonaga no ho made of thin material.

tit.j: 神職・巫女・稚児装束
tit.e: Costumes of Shinto priest, shrine maiden, and chigo (a child in a traditional festival procession).
Costumes of Shinto priest, shrine maiden, and chigo (a child in a traditional festival procession).
Costumes of Shinto priest, shrine maiden, and chigo (a child in a traditional festival procession).

sen.j: 明治以降国家によって祭祀制度が整えられていく際、神職の服制に関して衣冠・狩衣を用いるよう制度化された。
sen.e: In the process of organizing religious services by the government since the Meiji period, a new rule that a Shinto priest must wear ikan or kariginu was established.
In the process of organizing religious services by the government since the Meiji period, a new rule that a Shinto priest must wear ikan or kariginu was established.
In the process of organizing religious services by the government since the Meiji period, a new rule that a Shinto priest must wear ikan or kariginu was established.

sen.j: 男性神職装束：大祭式に衣冠、中祭式に斎服（白色の衣冠）、小祭式・その他の雑祭については狩衣或いは浄衣を用いる。
sen.e: Shinto priests' costume: ikan for daisaishiki (the grand festival ceremony), saifuku (the formal costume of a Shinto priest when performing religious ceremonies, made of white silk) for chusaishiki (the middle festival ceremony), kariginu or joe (a garment worn in religious ceremonies) for shosaishiki (the small festival ceremony) and other miscellaneous festivals.

Shinto priests' costume: ikan for daisaishiki (the grand festival ceremony), saifuku (the formal costume of a Shinto priest when performing religious ceremonies, made of white silk) for chusaishiki (the middle festival ceremony), kariginu or joe (a garment worn in religious ceremonies) for shosaishiki (the small festival ceremony) and other miscellaneous festivals.

Shinto priests' costume: ikan for daisaishiki (the grand festival ceremony), saifuku (the formal costume of a Shinto priest when performing religious ceremonies, made of white silk) for chusaishiki (the middle festival ceremony), kariginu or joe (a garment worn in religious ceremonies) for shosaishiki (the small festival ceremony) and other miscellaneous festivals.

sen.j: →神職

sen.j: 神楽装束：浦安の舞の装束が、十二単を参考に製作された。
sen.e: Costume for kagura (a performance of classical ceremonial music and dance): Costume of Urayasu no mai dance was created in the light of juni hitoe.
Costume for kagura (a performance of classical ceremonial music and dance): Costume of Urayasu no mai dance was created in the light of juni hitoe.
Costume for kagura (a performance of classical ceremonial music and dance): Costume of Urayasu no mai dance was created after the model of juni hitoe.

sen.j: 巫女装束：白小袖（白衣）に緋袴を履く点で平安装束の延長線にあると考えられる。
sen.e: Miko shozoku (costume for shrine maiden): it is considered that this costume inherited the Heian-style costume in that it requires white kosode and scarlet hakama.
Miko shozoku (costume for shrine maiden): it is considered that this costume inherited the Heian-style costume in that it requires white kosode and scarlet hakama.
